Does Not Meet Standard: Cannot import data or uses R Studio visual tools to import data.
Progressing Toward Standard: Manually organizes or modifies data before importing it into R.
Meets Standard: Can import raw data into R using the appropriate function for the data source.
Exceeds Standard: Can interface with APIs or other remote sources and import data directly into R.

Does Not Meet Standard: Cleans data in a non-programmatic way.
Progressing Toward Standard: Can clean data programmatically on a cell-by-cell basis to prepare it for analysis.
Meets Standard: Can assign the correct common data types (logical, integer, numeric, factor, and string) to loaded data and understand the uses of each. Can clean data for analysis in a vectorized way.
Exceeds Standard: Can prepare data for advanced types (dates, time series, etc.). Can prepare data from non-traditional sources such as OCR or web scraping.

Does Not Meet Standard: Formats data in a non-programmatic way.
Progressing Toward Standard: Can derive new measures from existing data and append it to dataframes.
Meets Standard: Can pivot data between wide and long formats, and can explain the use case of each.
Exceeds Standard: Can transition data between data frames and lists, and explain the applications of data in a list format.

Does Not Meet Standard: Transforms data in a non-programmatic way.
Progressing Toward Standard: Creates multiple copies of data in several intermediate stages of transformation that are used for different steps of analysis.
Meets Standard: Can combine and split data sets using the appropriate merge or subset techniques.
Exceeds Standard: Can split or merge data sets using either SQL-like calls or approximate matching.

Does Not Meet Standard: Copies-and-pastes similar code with small changes.
Progressing Toward Standard: Creates simple functions with consistent inputs.
Meets Standard: Creates simple functions that can handle novel inputs, with logic to handle the data appropriately.
Exceeds Standard: Creates complex functions that can handle arbitrary input. Includes built in error checking and warnings.

Does Not Meet Standard: Copies-and-pastes similar code several times within or between scripts.
Progressing Toward Standard: Uses for loops or apply functions to iterate through vector data to preform a single data manipulation.
Meets Standard: Can use either loops or apply functions to iterate over a vector of data and preform multi-step manipulations.
Exceeds Standard: Can use loops or apply functions and explain the use cases for each. Can iterate over complex data structures such as dataframes or lists.

Does Not Meet Standard: Selects inappropriate formats for data visualization.
Progressing Toward Standard: Selects sub-optimal visualization formats or uses excessive visualizations where a single one would be sufficient.
Meets Standard: Selects suitable formats for data visualization (bar, line, boxplot, etc.) and can explain the reasoning behind that choice.
Exceeds Standard: Effectively mixes visualization formats or isolates individual elements to clearly communicate a message.

Does Not Meet Standard: Chooses visual cues and colors for purely aesthetic reasons without attention to data representation.
Progressing Toward Standard: Data visualizations attempt to represent underlying data, but use methods unsuited to the task which leave ambiguity for the viewer.
Meets Standard: Data visualizations use color, scale, and shapes effectively to differentiate and communicate underlying data.
Exceeds Standard: Data visualizations are highly customized with bespoke elements, such as callouts, to clearly communicate the message of the visualization. Aesthetics are sensitive to accessibility concerns.

Does Not Meet Standard: Produces data visualizations that are unclear, confusing, devoid of context, or impossible to understand without reading the text.
Progressing Toward Standard: Produces data visualizations with readable axis labels, units, and legends (where appropriate).
Meets Standard: Produces data visualizations that are clear and understandable with minimal textual explanation.
Exceeds Standard: Produces data visualizations that are self-contained and can be understood on their own without textual explanation.

Does Not Meet Standard: Does not consider data ethics or investigate data provenance.
Progressing Toward Standard: Can articulate common pitfalls and relate them to the project at hand. Confirms data types and scales using data documentation.
Meets Standard: Reads data documentation to understand data collection/generation and measurements. Can highlight potential concerns specific to the data or project.
Exceeds Standard: Either creates data documentation for used data, or includes notes in code to the data sources and explains potential pitfalls. Considers and articulates relevant concerns related to the current project unprompted throughout the work cycle.

Does Not Meet Standard: Code style is inconsistent and/or lacks documentation.
Progressing Toward Standard: Code comments explain the broad strokes of intended behavior. Indentation is consistent and predictable. Uses print statements to track the status of code execution.
Meets Standard: Consistently comments all code with clearly organized sections. Expected inputs and outputs are clearly explained. Uses error messages or print statements within their code to locate the causes of errors and resolve them.
Exceeds Standard: Code is clearly commented, with standardized formatting and indentation. Code contains tests which will check for errors, and report those errors if they arise.

Does Not Meet Standard: Does not use git for version control.
Progressing Toward Standard: Uses git and GitHub for version control and can contribute to group repositories with commits, pushes, and pulls.
Meets Standard: Uses git and GitHub effectively. Code commits are of appropriate size and commented well. Can branch and merge repositories while resolving any merge conflicts. Does not include sensitive files in commits.
Exceeds Standard: Uses Github effectively for collaboration. Can create issues, ask for review, and merge branches in a manner suitable for a collaborative environment.
